page.title: 01North Norfolk Coast at Wells
page.content: A Sanddune ridge thirty feet high, covered with spacious pinewoods forming a nature conservancy council reserve always open to the public and called Holkham Meals, runs east-west. It has a coastguard lookout and lifeboat station at its eastern end. North is the beach with miles of sandflats at low tide. South lies ditch-drained aragle farmland, parking for 500 cars, and a caravan park accommodating 4000 holidaymakers in summer, and geese, gulls and waders in winter. An office and five shops operate at the caravan park in summer employing twenty people. The only full-time jobs in winter are Nature Reserve Warden, Coastguard, and Caravan Park Manager. About 24 times a month a pilot steers a 400 ton ship through the sandbanks into Wells. Birdwatching is popular with Twitchers
